newsitem.title: USA: U.S. CREDIT MARKET OUTLOOK - Whither the economy?.
newsitem.headline: U.S. CREDIT MARKET OUTLOOK - Whither the economy?.

text.p: The Treasury's refunding next week will occupy the attention of debt market participants, as they continue to sort out what this past week's full menu of economic data means for the U.S. economy.

The Treasury will sell $16 billion in three-year notes, $12.0 billion in 10-year notes and $10.0 billion in 30-year bonds next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Market players said the refunding should occupy more attention than next week's economic data which will include the Federal Reserve's Beige Book, June chain store sales and June consumer credit.

After a barrage of surprisingly strong economic data sent 30-year Treasury bonds plummeting more than two points Friday, "The refunding will be the central focus of next week," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy.
"I doubt if the Beige Book will give any indication of a Fed move," Liro said. "The real focus is how the market handles the supply,"

After Friday's back-up in rates, said Liro, "It should be a lot easier to take down these auctions than when it was with the 10-year note below 6.0 percent which is where it was before the jobs number."

The market was stunned by Friday's July jobs data that was much stronger than expected; the unemployment rate fell to 4.8 percent and 316,000 nonfarm jobs were created. Then the National Association of Purchasing Management index of July manufacturing activity rose to 58.6 percent, its highest in 2-1/2 years. Meanwhile, the University of Michigan released its July final index of consumer sentiment, which soared to an all-time high of 107.1 from 104.5 in the final June report.
Treasury prices, which rallied for for consecutive days through Thursday fell sharply Friday amid repeated signs the nation's economy may be stronger than the market had thought.

"The economy is showing some strengthening in the third quarter and interest rates have shown significant declines. Some of the euphoria is now coming out of the market," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Barnett Bank Inc.
Prior to Friday's strong data, Reaser contended, next week's refunding was "largely discounted in the market."

She said June consumer credit data, to be released Thursday, Augusts 7, could provide clues to consumer confidence. Otherwise, Reaser said, "It should be a pretty slow week in terms of numbers. The market will be adjusting to this week's numbers which showed some rebound in July."
John Williams, managing director and chief global markets economist at Bankers Trust Co, agreed that participants in the Treasury market "likely will digest the blizzard of data it got this week.
"People are looking to see if there is any hint of a strong second half in the nation's economy," said Williams, referring to the Fed's beige book, to be released Wednesday, August 6..
"I suspect that it will confirm there is a lot of economic momentum. The market's euphoria has been built on a benign inflation backdrop," he added.

"If the economy shows some strengthening we can move to 6.5 percent to 7.0 percent, particuarly if the economy shows signs of strengthening and talk of a (Federal Reserve) tightening later in the year crops up," Reaser said.

Reaser said she believed signs of vigor hinted at by Friday's economic data may reignite expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate move later this year. "Employment and the purchasing management index all show the economy is far from dead," she said.
Williams noted that Treasury prices gave "quite a concession" Friady and "the refunding next week will go OK at these levels."

Liro predicted next week's refunding should pick up momentum as the week progresses. So, while three-year notes may not see as lively investor interest, the 30-year bonds should be well received, he said.
